newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea won hits 6-yr low, central bank intervenes.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea won hits 6-yr low, central bank intervenes.

text.p: South Korea's central bank intervened to protect the won on Wednesday after the currency slid to a fresh six-year low of 830 on heavy demand for U.S. dollars by importers, traders said.
It is the won's lowest level since South Korea introduced a market average system in March 1990.
"It looks like the central bank began to sell dollars when the won fell to a new six-year low of 830," said a dealer with a domestic bank.

The won slid as far as 829.50 before the central Bank of Korea stabilised the currency. By 0225 GMT, it was trading at 829.90 and dealers said they expected it to move between 827.00 and 830.00 in the afternoon.
The won last hit a six-year high on September 16 at 830.00.
"The U.S. dollar is rising on import deals and bullish sentiment," one local dealer said.
